description: Hardy epiphyte that attaches to wood or stone. Do not bury the rhizome.
Narrow-leaf variety of Java fern; good for smaller scapes and detail work.
Decorative Java fern variant with forked leaf tips.
Fern-like epiphyte that prefers stable, soft water and good flow.
Slow-growing rhizome plant that tolerates low light and is ideal for hardscape.
Larger anubias with broad leaves; slow and algae-resistant in low light.
Very small anubias variant ideal for nano tanks and detailed hardscape.
Textured anubias variety with ruffled leaves and slow growth.
Versatile moss for shrimp tanks and fry cover. Can be tied to hardscape or used as a mesh carpet.
Moss with triangular fronds that resemble Christmas tree branches.
Upright-growing moss with a flame-like shape in good conditions.
Moss that grows downward in a weeping pattern when attached to wood or stone.
Slow-growing premium epiphyte with wavy green leaves. Benefits from stable conditions and good flow.
Compact buce variety with narrow leaves.
Sensitive buce variety; prefers stability and clean water.
Large rosette plant and heavy root feeder. Benefits from nutrient-rich substrate or root tabs.
Smaller sword plant for midground placement; heavy root feeder.
Hardy crypt with many color variants. May melt when moved but typically recovers.
Hardy crypt often used for midground; tolerates low light.
Small crypt that stays short; growth is slow and improves with CO2.
Tall crypt with long, ribbon-like leaves; likes stable conditions and root nutrition.
Grass-like plant that spreads via runners. Can form a short lawn in good conditions.
Foreground runner plant that can form a short lawn under decent light.
Compact bushy foreground plant; trims into a low hedge.
Textured rosette-like plant; needs strong light and CO2 to stay compact.
Popular carpeting plant that typically needs high light and CO2 to stay compact and carpet.
Fine grass-like carpet that spreads via runners; CO2 helps density.
Shorter hairgrass variant; typically needs CO2 and strong light to carpet tightly.
Creeping plant that can form a low carpet; may show clover-like leaves at first.
Classic high-tech carpeting plant; will grow upward without enough light.
Very small-leaved carpet; typically demands CO2, strong light, and stable nutrients.
Fast creeping plant with clover-like leaves; can overtake scapes if not trimmed.
Fast-growing nutrient sponge and great beginner stem plant. Can be planted or floated.
Extremely fast-growing stem plant; great for new tanks and algae control.
Feathery fast-growing stem plant that responds well to trimming.
Thick-stemmed plant with rounded leaves; slower than many stems but hardy.
Fast grower that can be planted or floated; tolerates a wide range of conditions.
Fast-growing stem plant. Color and compact growth improve with stronger light and CO2.
High-tech rotala variant that colors best under strong light and CO2.
Demanding red stem plant; sensitive to CO2 stability and water hardness.
Hardy red-tinged stem plant; color improves with stronger light.
Vibrant red stem plant; strong light helps maintain deep color.
Compact red stem plant that needs strong light and CO2 to stay low and dense.

notes: Photo and citation are for a Vallisneria spiralis variant ("Tiger"). Care requirements are generally similar but can vary by strain.
description: Hardy background plant with ribbon leaves; spreads quickly via runners.
Tall val for large tanks; can quickly fill in the background.
Fast-growing stem-like plant that can be floated or anchored; great nutrient sponge.
Hardy oxygenating plant; grows quickly under moderate light.
Fast-growing stem plant with thin leaves; easy and forgiving.
Fine, conifer-like stem plant with tight growth under strong light and CO2.
Grass-like rosette plant; strong light and CO2 help maintain compact form.

Cladophora aegagropila is not really a plant, but a ball of algae. It is a decorative exception from the rule about avoiding algae at all costs. It is normally found in shallow lakes, where the movement of the waves forms it into a sphere. In an aquarium it must be turned regularly to keep it in shape. It can be divided into smaller pieces, which become spherical with time, or which form a carpet if attached to roots and stones.
notes: Not really a plant: it is a ball of algae. Turn it periodically for even light and shape.

description: Very demanding rosette plant that prefers soft, acidic water and strong light.
High-demand stem plant that prefers soft, acidic water; sensitive to instability.
Floating liverwort often tied to mesh or stones to create a bright green carpet effect.
Fine-textured epiphyte/liverwort that grows slowly; benefits from CO2 and clean water.
Floating plant that reduces nitrates and shades the tank; may be messy in high flow.
Floating plant with long roots; great nitrate sponge and fish/shrimp cover.
Small floating fern that spreads quickly; easy to remove by scooping.
Tiny floating plant that grows extremely fast; excellent nutrient export but hard to fully remove.
Unique fern-like leaves; can be planted or attached to hardscape. Colors and form improve with CO2.
Fast-growing small-leaf stem plant; can be trimmed into a bushy midground.
Grass-like carpet plant that spreads slowly; CO2 improves density.
Bulb plant with red leaves; can send floating leaves if allowed. Benefits from root nutrition.
Colorful stem plant with aromatic leaves; best in soft water with strong light and CO2.
Fine-leaved rotala that demands strong light, CO2 stability, and soft water.
Showy rotala variant with compact growth under strong light and CO2.
Fine feathery stem plant; colors best with CO2 and strong light in softer water.
Delicate feathery stem plant; needs cleaner water and stronger light than many easy stems.
Wavy-leaf crypt that tolerates low light; can melt when moved but often recovers.
High-tech stem plant with narrow leaves; needs strong light, CO2, and consistent nutrients for best color.
